translated: Birth Stories🔽The Fives
The Chapter with Vaṇṇāroha
The Birth Story of Tacasāra
“You are in the hands of your enemies,
covered in a shroud;
Your face is pale—
why are you not grieving?”
“Not by grieving or lamenting

analyzed: atthaḥ uva labbhaḥ api appakaḥ pi
translated: will any good come of it, even if it is little;
When they see you grieving and miserable,

original: Paccatthikā attamanā bhavanti.🔽Yato ca kho paṇḍito āpadāsu,
analyzed: paccatthikāḥ attamanāḥ bhavanti  yatas ca kho paṇḍitaḥ āpadāsu
translated: your enemies will be delighted.🔽But when the wise one, who knows how to judge what is good,
is not overcome by misfortune,
his enemies will be miserable,
seeing his face unchanged as before.
By muttering spells, by mantras, by good sayings,
by gifts, by favoritism,
whatever good you can get from wherever,
there you should strive in that way.
But when you know that it is impossible

original: Mayā va aññena vā esa attho;
analyzed: mayā va aññena vā esa attho
translated: to get this good for yourself or anyone else,
you should live without grieving,

analyzed: kammam daḷham kinti karomi dāni iti
translated: thinking, ‘What strong deed can I do now?’”
The Birth Story of Tacasāra is the eighth.
